history.text: Hi, we're talking about The Wolf of Wall Street.
Hi, the Wolf of Wall Street is an interesting movie but I've never watched it.
It's pretty cool. Leonardo DiCaprio is in it. It's a black comedy.
Yeah, I love Leonardo DiCaprio's acting prowess. However, I've heard that it also has some very vulgar language and scenes.
Oh yes, it is very vulgar. There's also a lot of drug use.
I don't understand why every good movie has to include some profane language or scenes in order to be seen by people. I believe movies can be good without profanity.
Yeah, I think in this movie they were really trying to make it part of the corrupt stockbroker character.
Okay, so I guess part of the life of a corrupt stockbrocker is drug use, profanity and balck comedy which they had to show.
I guess. If you can get past that, I think it's pretty good. It didn't have great reviews though.
I can imagine, with all the profanity I keep hearing that it has, many people might not have seen passed the drug abuse, profanity and black humour.
It is sort of interesting to see how he goes from selling penny stocks to having a small fortune by the end!
Oh, so he starts selling small penny stocks and through corruption and taking advantage of the loops within the system he gets a fortune...interesting.
Yeah, he's super aggressive in his selling, so he moves through the ranks really quickly.
I guess being a go-getter is what made him super aggressive and hence allows him to move quickly up the ranks.
He's very focused on making money for himself, so greed is certainly a motivating factor.

"Self" is the greatest motivator for a human being. So just by focusing on making money for himself and being greedy, he was able to build a fortune within a small time...it only get's more intriguing.
And after he made a lot of money at the small stock place, he left and opened his own firm so he could do even more shady stuff.

What a corrupt guy...he comes from a small stock place where maybe he had to jump through hoops and loops in order to do shady deals and opens his own firm where he can be unrestricted in his corruption...this is wickedness
And he gets all sorts of promising young brokers to work for him
This is now misleading even young brokers and teaching them to be as corrupt as he is...another level of wickedness
Yeah, not a great dude. He even ends up cheating on his wife and then marrying the mistress.
His corruption even extends to his family?...He cheats on his own wife and marries a mistress just because he can? This movie may lead many men astray.
She ends up divorcing him though
At least she gets her freedom from him through a divorce, good for her.
He ends up getting arrested too and the firm is shut down when his partner rats on him
Finally there is justice in this whole story. So his partner actually rats on him and he gets arrested and his shady firm is closed, this is what I call poetic justice.
If only his punishment was more harsh. He wasn't in prison for long.
What?? How long was he jailed for, I hope not a few years...
only 3 years.
This just shows you that there is no justice in this world's system. He should be jailed for more than 10 years not just 3 years.
I feel like he ended up being a bit of a joke though.

uid2response.feedback: Through the discussion that I had with the other user, I have come to learn that "The Wolf of Wall Street" is not just about profanity and corruption but about a wicked world's system that can corrupt a man and lead him astray, yet even when he is judged, he is not given a harsh punishment in the end. This has given me the motivation to watch the movie.
